Question 1.Question: What subject is this?
Question 1.Explanation: This is Economics.

Question 2.Question: Economics is the study of human behavior as it relates to the
Question 2.Explanation: Economics is the study of human behaviors as a relationship between ends and scarce means which have alternatives forgone (i.e. opportunity cost). It relates to efficient allocation of resources.

Options.Value: Efficient allocation of resources
The regulatory nature of the market
The invisible hand
Consumer rationality

Question 3.Question: The downturn in the prices of shares on stock markets is a highlight of
Question 3.Explanation: Changes in the prices of shares in stock market are usually caused by market forces of demand and supply which is also referred to as the invisible hand. In his first book, "The Theory of Moral Sentiments," Adams Smith proposed the idea of an invisible hand — the tendency of free markets to regulate themselves by means of competition, supply and demand, and self-interest.

Question 4.Explanation:
∑fx = X × N

= 6 x 6

= 36

Question 5.Explanation: Standard deviation is one of the measures of dispersion. Others include mean deviation, range and variance.

Question 6.Explanation: The mean is the best measure of central of tendency because it is a balancing point in an observation.

Question 7.Explanation: The mode of a set of data values is the value that appears most often. It is the most occurring frequency or observation.

Question 8.Question: If the demand for a good is more elastic than its supply, the tax burden is borne
Question 8.Explanation: When elasticity of demand for a good is more elastic than its supply, the burden must be borne by the producer otherwise; there will be loss in revenue as the consumer may respond greatly to price increases due to addition of tax.

Be constant
Increase

Question 9.Explanation: An increase in price of a good whose demand is elastic leads to a decrease in the revenue if the producer or seller.

Question 10.Question: An excess demand for beans will result from
Question 10.Explanation: Excess demand of any good will only result from the low price. This obeys the law of demand that when the price of a good is decreased, there will be an increase in the quantity demanded.

Question 11.Question: Consumer surplus tends to be higher when demand is
Question 11.Explanation: Consumers' surplus is the difference between what a consumer is willing to pay for a commodity and what he actually does pay for it. When demand is inelastic, change in price may not necessitate much change in quantity demanded.

Total utility is a function of price
Utility can be ranked

Question 12.Explanation: Ordinalist believed that utility is ranked while Cardinalist believed that utility can be measured.

Question 13.Question: The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why
Question 13.Explanation: The law of diminishing marginal utility theory explains why the slope of a normal demand curve is negative. The Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility states that all else equal as consumption increases the marginal utility derived from each additional unit declines.

Question 16.Explanation: Supply is fairly elastic if the coefficient of PES is greater than unit (1). If the coefficient of PES is zero, it is perfectly inelastic.

Question 17.Question: If commodity X is a by-product of commodity Y, this implies that both commodities are
Question 17.Explanation: The two commodities are composite in supply. When two or more goods and/or services are combined to make a bundle, it is known as acomposite supply. Thecomposite supplyincludes a main or principal component which is essential to the purpose of the bundle.

Question 18.Question: In perfect competition, price is determined by the
Question 18.Explanation: It takes the price as decided by the forces of demand and supply, that is, the market. No firm can influence the price of the product.

Question 19.Question: In order to reduce hardship faced by consumers due to high prices, government can introduce
Question 19.Explanation: Price control boards would enable to fix prices for all essential goods. Question 20.Question: Average product is less than marginal product when
Question 20.Explanation: Decreasing returns to scale set in when output increase in less proportion to increase in inputs.

Question 21.Question: A firm enjoying economics of scale is said to be
Question 21.Explanation: When firm reduces average production cost, a firm is said to be enjoying economics of scale. As long as the long run average cost curve is declining, then internal economies of scale are being exploited.

Diseconomies of scale
Economics of scale
Increasing marginal returns

Question 22.Question: The rising portion of the long-run average cost curve of a firm is an indication that it is experiencing
Question 22.Explanation: Diseconomies of scale happen when a company or business grows so large that the costs per unit increase. The rising portion of LRAC curve indicates that the firm is experiencing diseconomies of scale.

Question 24.Explanation: In monopolistic competition, there is a mobility of factors of production. Other characteristics are large numbers of buyers and sellers, perfect information, low entry and exit barriers, and similar but differentiated goods.

Question 25.Explanation: Demand for all factors of production is derived. The demand curve for factors of production is downward sloping indicating high prices give rise to low demand for factor of production.

Question 26.Question: An agreement among firms on price and segmentation is termed
Question 26.Explanation: A cartel is a formal agreement among firms in an oligopolistic industry. Cartel members may agree on such matters as prices, total industry output, market shares, allocation of customers, allocation of territories, bid-rigging, establishment of common sales agencies, and the division of profits or combination of these. An example of a cartel is Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).

Question 30.Question: The function of money which makes division of labor possible is its
Question 30.Explanation: Money as a medium of exchange allows division of labor and specialization. Money also encourages specialization. Without money, workers and other resources could not be paid except in the output produced.

Question 31.Question: By buying treasury bills, the Central Bank of Nigeria intends to
Question 31.Explanation: By buying Treasury Bills, the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) through Open Market Operation (OMO), increases the money in circulation. By selling Treasury Bills, they CBN is doing the opposite - reducing money supply in the economy.

Question 32.Question: The velocity of money is represented as
Question 32.Explanation:
Velocity of money refers to the speed at which money circulates within the economy by changing from one hand to another. When there is an increase in velocity of money in circulation, prices will increase thus leading to lower value of money.

Velocity of money = Money supply/Real GDP

Question 33.Question: One of the functions of commercial banks is
Question 33.Explanation: Apart from collecting deposit from customers, commercial banks grant loans to customers. The primary functions of a commercial bank are accepting deposits and lending funds. Question 34.Explanation: To curb unemployment using fiscal policy, government will increase spending and decrease its taxes.

Question 40.Explanation: Government takes active role on locating industries in order to spread development. Opening of new industries in different areas would lead to employment.
